title: 103_s765
content: The "Health Insurance Protection Act of 1993" may be cited as the Act. It provides protection from interference with rights. Section 510 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new subsection (b) which prohibits discrimination in canceling or reducing benefits under a group health plan based on specific diseases or medical conditions. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to prohibit discrimination in canceling or reducing benefits under a group health plan based on specific diseases or medical conditions. This includes ensuring that participants undergoing treatment related to a disease or medical condition have valid claims submitted before any benefit reduction. Additionally, there are special rules regarding plan terminations, where the employer must replace the plan to avoid the provisions of this subsection. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of terms related to group health plans, such as 'change in insured status' referring to shifts in self-insured status or the extent of benefits provided under a plan. It also defines 'insurer' as a licensed person providing benefits under a plan through an insurance contract. Additionally, it defines 'valid claim' as a claim that would have entitled the participant to benefits at the time of submission. The curr_chunk discusses the entitlement of a participant or beneficiary to benefits under a plan. The curr_chunk introduces a new section on nondiscrimination in lifetime benefit coverage under a group health plan in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Sec. 516 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 prohibits group health plans from discriminating among diseases or medical conditions in lifetime benefit coverage provided to participants and beneficiaries. Lifetime benefit coverage refers to the maximum aggregate benefit available to individuals under the plan. This section does not apply if certain requirements, such as collective bargaining, are met for participants and their beneficiaries. The requirements for collective bargaining under Sec. 516 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 include participants covered by a collective bargaining agreement, evidence of good faith bargaining for benefits, and discrimination based on variations in collective bargaining agreement terms for separate facilities. The group health plan sponsor can seek exemption from certain requirements if they can prove to the Secretary that they will be unable to continue the plan without relief, following an exemption procedure established by the Secretary. The group health plan sponsor can seek exemption from certain requirements by proving to the Secretary their inability to continue the plan without relief. The exemption will be subject to standards and procedures similar to those under section 408(a) of the Act. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in section 1 of the Act. Sec. 515. Delinquent contributions and Sec. 516. Nondiscrimination in lifetime benefit coverage under a group health plan. SEC. 4. REPORTING AND DISCLOSURE REQUIREMENTS. Section 104(b)(1) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to require a 60-day notice period for any material coverage restrictions in a group health plan before they can take effect. The notice must be provided in easily understood language to participants and their spouses. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 now requires a 60-day notice period for any significant coverage changes in a group health plan. This includes increased deductibles or coinsurance payments. Self-insured group health plans must also provide specific information in their plan descriptions. Self-insured group health plans must provide specific information in their plan descriptions, including identifying the responsible person for claim determinations and indicating that the plan is not subject to State guarantee fund protection. The term 'group health plan' is defined as provided in section 607(1), and a plan is considered 'self-insured' unless all benefits are provided under a contract or policy of insurance issued by a State-licensed person. A self-insured group health plan is considered self-insured unless all benefits are provided under a contract or policy of insurance issued by a State-licensed person. SEC. 5. Legal relief from damages for interference with rights under the plan. Section 502(c) of ERISA is amended to allow for actual and consequential damages for violations of certain sections related to group health plans. Punitive damages may be awarded in cases of willful, fraudulent, or malicious conduct, bad faith, or gross negligence, up to 200 percent of actual damages but not less than $50,000. The amendment allows for attorney's fees to be awarded in actions for damages under subsection (c)(4) of ERISA, with fees to be paid by the defendant if the plaintiff prevails. The amendments made by this Act will apply to changes in group health plan coverage adopted after the enactment of the Act.
